item.title: French Embassy in Libya Attacked
item.description: The explosion of a car parked outside the French Embassy injured two security guards, and French authorities called for a rapid investigation.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: The French embassy in Tripoli, Libya, was attacked by what appeared to be a car bomb on Tuesday.-

item.title: Forged Hitler Diaries Now Part of Germany’s Archives
item.description: The magazine Stern handed over 60 handwritten volumes that it published in 1983, mistakenly claiming they were Hitler’s undiscovered journals, to Germany’s Federal Archives for posterity.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS COTTRELL and NICHOLAS KULISH

item.title: Israel and Palestinians Reach Deal on Unesco
item.description: The agreement on involvement by the United Nations cultural agency in sensitive areas of Jerusalem was a small but significant breakthrough.
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: At War Blog: Running Toward the Boston Marathon Chaos
item.description: Zachary Edward Bell said he saw something more jaw-dropping than the Boston Marathon tragedy itself: people, many of them civilians, running toward the chaos.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ZACHARY BELL
item.media:description: An image taken from video shows an explosion near the finish line.

item.title: Tensions Flare Between China and Japan Over Islands and Shrine
item.description: Lawmakers in Tokyo visited a shrine whose symbolism has angered China, while the two nations squared off over contested islands.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Japanese vessels sailed near a Chinese surveillance ship near disputed islands called Senkaku in Japan and Diaoyu in China on Tuesday.

item.title: Tensions Flare Between China and Japan Over Islands and Shrine
item.description: Lawmakers in Tokyo visited a shrine whose symbolism has angered China, while the two nations squared off over contested islands.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER
item.media:description: Japanese vessels sailed near a Chinese surveillance ship near disputed islands called Senkaku in Japan and Diaoyu in China on Tuesday.

item.title: Key Step in Checking Chemical-Arms Use Is Also Hardest
item.description: Independent experts hope to get prompt, unfettered access to the site of any suspected attack, but that is very difficult in the Syrian conflict.
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD

item.title: WORLD: Same-Sex Marriage and the French Family
item.description: While activists demonstrate over President François Hollande's politics, French parents debate the legalization of adoption for gay married couples.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships

item.title: Bombing Suspect Cites Islamic Extremist Beliefs as Motive
item.description: Dzhokhar Tsarnaev, the surviving suspect in the Boston Marathon attacks, said he and his brother were not connected to any known terrorist groups, law enforcement officials said.
item.dc:creator: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE, MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and WILLIAM K. RASHBAUM
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times
item.media:description: Zubeidat Tsarnaeva, center, the mother of two alleged Boston bombers, near her home in Makhachkala, the capital of the Republic of Dagestan, on Tuesday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 23
item.description: A woman rides a scooter in the rain, in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A woman driving a scooter in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh, with portraits of women in traditional attire visible by the roadside.

item.title: Two Kidnapped Syrian Bishops Freed-Church Official
item.description: Kidnappers freed two Syrian bishops on Tuesday who had been abducted in the northern city of Aleppo, a church official said, but the identities of their kidnappers remained uncertain.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: France Approves Same-Sex Marriage
item.description: The passage of the “marriage for all” law by the lower house of Parliament came after months of sometimes angry debate and a series of major protests.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE
item.media:description: People celebrated with Champagne outside the French national assembly in Paris on Tuesday.

item.title: Israel Says Syria Has Used Chemical Weapons
item.description: A military official criticized the world community on Tuesday for failing to respond to evidence of chemical weapons attacks in Syria, which President Obama has called a “red line” that cannot be crossed.
item.category: National Coalition of Syrian Revolutionary and Opposition Forces
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN and DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: U.S. Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel met a group of Israeli soldiers during his visit to a an army base near Tel Aviv on Tuesday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Horse Doping Scandal Rocks Dubai’s Rulers
item.description: Dubai’s ruling family is a dominant force in the horseracing world. The revelation that some of their top thoroughbreds were administered banned streoids is being described as “hugely embarrassing.”
item.category: shiekh mohammed bin rashid al maktoum
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Sheikh Mohammed, center, during the Dubai World Cup on March 30.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: How China’s ‘Leftover Women’ Are to Blame
item.description: With Chinese women who are unmarried in their late 20s stigmatized as “leftover,” a feminist explains their own traditional attitudes may, in some cases, be holding them back.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: Many professional women in China demand mates who make more than they do.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: What’s French for ‘Family’?
item.description: Amid an historic and acrimonious debate in France over marriage rights for same-sex couples, Stefania Rousselle profiles two French families on opposite sides.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE

item.title: France Legalizes Gay Marriage After Harsh Debate
item.description: France legalized gay marriage on Tuesday after a wrenching national debate and protests that flooded the streets of Paris. Legions of officers and water cannon stood ready near France's National Assembly ahead of the final vote, bracing for possible violence on an issue that galvanized the country's faltering conservative movement.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Jonas Kaufmann, Nina Stemme Named Best Singers at Opera Awards
item.description: The Opera Awards, in their first year, honored achievement during 2012 and were determined by a 10-person jury, following nominations from the public.
item.dc:creator: By GEORGE LOOMIS

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Britain's church joins country's spy agencies in warnings to Cameron
item.description: Both the archbishop of Canterbury and the British spy services issued scathing assessments of Prime Minister David Cameron’s handling of the economy.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: The Female Factor: Rejecting the 'Leftover Women' Label
item.description: Chinese society has long told women to get married by 25, lest they become old and undesriable. But proudly single professionals are pushing back against the stereotype.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW

item.title: Iran Rejects Canadian Terrorism Charge
item.description: Iran on Tuesday strongly rejected Canadian police claims that a planned terrorist attack to derail a passenger train was linked to Al Qaeda elements on its soil.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: India Ink: What They Said: Former Chief Justice Jagdish Sharan Verma’s Death
item.description: He led a commission which looked into violence against women in India following the Dec. 16 Delhi gang rape.
item.dc:creator: By NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: Jagdish Sharan Verma, former chief justice of India, left, with then President A.P.J. Abdul Kalam at a Human Rights conference in New Delhi on Dec. 10, 2002.

item.title: Clashes at Sunni Protest Site in Iraq Kill 33
item.description: An attack on a Sunni protest encampment in a village near the northern city of Kirkuk raised the stakes sharply in Iraq’s sectarian troubles.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: China’s Criticism of U.S. on Human Rights Draws Support (and Mockery)
item.description: Many Chinese netizens were unimpressed by a state report criticizing the U.S. human rights situation, which focused on gun violence, among other things.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from the Sina Weibo account of Xinhua, the state-run news agency, showing an annoyed Uncle Sam surrounded by points detailing China's criticisms of human rights in the United States. The main criticism is gun violence.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 23
item.description: Pollution radically changes childhood in China; Germany fines Google; a former soccer champion faces prison; the deaths of a Woodstock musician and a Cuban cinema giant.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Students at the International School of Beijing playing in one of two domes with air-filtration systems for when smog is severe.
